TopicTitle: High inclination Launch Center in Germany?

Articles.Content:
I found someone made plans fo a Space Center in Peenemuende/Germany. It says that there would be Falcon and Atlas V launches at the place, where Wernher von Braun developed and tested his Aggregat 4 rocket and invented the time of space flight. The place is at 54Ã‚Â° 8', so there could be flights with an inclination from 54Ã‚Â° to 90Ã‚Â° in order to not flying over countryside. What do you think of this?

Edited December 25, 2013 by Nephf
It very much depends on who that someone is

If you're going to build a space center in western Europe Peenemuende might indeed be one of the better locations. It's location on the Baltic coast gives it a wide open area to the east where failing rockets can't do too much damage.

With a latitude of 54Ã‚Â° 8' it isn't even too far off the ISS' maximum inclination (51.65Ã‚Â°).

P.S.

A link to your source would be appreciated by many.

A link to your source would be appreciated by many.

Sorry but this wasn't any web source

Don't get me wrong, I like this to be true. But without any reliable source this is just hearsay and scuttlebutt.

Both the Atlas V and Falcon 9 mentioned on the map are modern rockets. Therefor the 'plan' must date from no later than the turn of the century. The only things I have been able to find thus far on a PeenemÃƒÂ¼nde space center is either WWII related or fictional.

So I now found it. It's a local Facebook site.

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=623703147687453&set=a.623703207687447.1073741826.623701394354295&type=1&theater

How? I hear you say. Easy! I let some Google-Fu loose on that image and guess what I found: That images is NOT the so called PeenemÃƒÂ¼nde Space Center but is in fact Space Launch Complex 41 at Cape Canaveral.

So called PeenemÃƒÂ¼nde Space Center: https://www.facebook.com/wvbsc

Space Launch Complex 41: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Canaveral_Air_Force_Station_Space_Launch_Complex_41

I don't think the norweigans, finns balts or russians would would. Given the length of time the first stage on a falcon 9 burns, the drop zone would probably be outside the baltic; definitely so for a polar launch.
As Falcon 9 is completely reuseable, the drop zone is exactly the launch site.

I KNOW Kodiak Launch Complex. But if you wish to use it as a common launch center for Rockets with payloads heavier than 2 tons, you have to build as much infrastructure as if you would build a launchpad on the moon, because it is located in the middle of nothing .

PeenemÃƒÂ¼nde has a little history.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xFZudxPNYcQ
I know that film already. of course no rocket launched from there since 1945. But its location is very well for flights.

Sorry m1xte but you don't say.

As if somebody wouldn't know that.

I KNOW Kodiak Launch Complex. But if you wish to use it as a common launch center for Rockets with payloads heavier than 2 tons, you have to build as much infrastructure as if you would build a launchpad on the moon, because it is located in the middle of nothing .

There are thousands of people on Kodiak, and a large USCG base; it's not as if we're talking about Antarctica here. It's certainly got a lot more relevant infrastructure than PeenemÃƒÂ¼nde, unless you're proposing reusing PrÃƒÂ¼fstand VII.

So if you have a look at the Pictures you'll see that the 2 fictional pads are about 1-2 kilometers away from the old one, and fact is that Kodiak was opened 15 years ago and had 3 successful orbital launche now, and these were Athena I (820 kg LEO) and Minotaur IV (1745kg LEO) launchers. The Minotaur IV has 2/3 the diameter, 2x the hight and 9x the thrust of the A 4.
